p: Commonly used PCMs include organic PCMs such as paraffin, fatty acids, and polyethylene glycol (PEG) [ 72, 73, 74, 75]. Commercial paraffins are inexpensive and have considerable storage density (200 kJ/kg or 150 MJ/m 3). Their supercooling effect is negligible, and they have stable chemical and physical properties as well as good thermal stability. Phase-change materials with these characteristics can be used in applications under a wide range of temperatures, for example, in the construction sector [ 5]. However, paraffin has a low thermal conductivity, that is, with an average of 0.2 W/mK, which is much lower than some common organic PCM solutions (0.8 W/mK).
